paper_title: Cu2O-tipped ZnO nanorods with enhanced photoelectrochemical performance for CO2 photoreduction

catalyst.source: Cu2O-tipped ZnO nanorods with enhanced photoelectrochemical performance for CO2 photoreduction
catalyst.context: Cu2O-tipped ZnO nanorods with enhanced photoelectrochemical performance for CO2 photoreduction

catalyst.llm generation: Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO nanorods / ZnO/Cu 2 O structures
catalyst.source: This work shows that Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO nanorods possess improved behavior of charge generation, separation and transport, which may work as a potential candidate for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.
catalyst.context: The design of Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO nanorods is proposed here aiming at enhanced photoelectrochemical properties.The tip-selective deposition of Cu 2 O is confirmed by scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM).The photoinduced charge behavior like charge generation, separation and transport has been thoroughly studied by UV-vis absorption analysis and different photoelectrochemical characterizations, including transient photocurrent, incident photon-to-current efficiency (IPCE), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), intensity-modulated photocurrent spectroscopy (IMPS), and Mott-Schottky measurements.The photoelectrochemical characterizations clearly indicate that ZnO/Cu 2 O structures exhibit much higher performance than pristine ZnO, due to the formation of p-n junction, as well as the tip selective growth of Cu 2 O on ZnO.Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in aqueous solution under UV-visible light illumination shows that CO is the main product, and with the increase of the Cu 2 O content in the heterostructure, the CO yield increases.This work shows that Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO nanorods possess improved behavior of charge generation, separation and transport, which may work as a potential candidate for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.

catalyst.source: The ZnO nanorods with Cu 2 O at the tips were synthesized via photochemical deposition.
catalyst.context: All the chemicals used in this work including zinc nitrate (Zn(NO 3 )6H 2 O, 99.9), copper sulfate (CuSO 4 , 99.9), potassium chloride (KCl, 99.9), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99.9) and lactic acid (C 3 H 6 O 3 , 99.9) were purchased from Sinogrham Chemicals.The chemicals were of analytical grade and used without any further purification.FTO (Fluorine-doped tin oxide) glass (14 sq -1 ) was bought from Wuhan Jinge Solar Energy Technology Co., Ltd, China.The Milli-Q water was used throughout the experiments. The ZnO nanorods were prepared by electrochemical deposition method using an aqueous solution composed of 1 mmolL -1 Zn(NO 3 )6H 2 O and 0.1 molL -1 KCl.The FTO substrate was used as the working electrode, platinum as the counter electrode, and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode.The electrodeposition was carried out under the bias of -1.045 V for 150 min at a temperature of 70 C.Finally, the as-prepared ZnO nanorods were rinsed thoroughly with Milli-Q water to remove the residuals. The ZnO nanorods with Cu 2 O at the tips were synthesized via photochemical deposition.The aqueous solution with 1 mmolL -1 CuSO 4 and 5 methanol was prepared as the precursor, of which the pH value was adjusted to 9.0 by NaOH.The lactic acid was used as stabilizer to avoid precipitation.The as-prepared ZnO nanorods were immersed into the above solution for Cu 2 O photodeposition.Before the deposition, the solution was deaerated by Ar gas for 30 min in dark, and then it was illuminated with a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300, 470 mWcm -2 ) for 30, 45 and 60 s, respectively. The as-synthesized samples were then rinsed with Milli-Q water and pure ethanol, and finally vacuum dried at 60 oC.In this work, the ZnO/Cu 2 O heterostructures prepared under different illumination times are respectively denoted as ZnO/Cu 2 O-30s, ZnO/Cu 2 O-45s, and ZnO/Cu 2 O-60s. The crystallinity of the obtained samples was investigated by X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation (D8 Focus, Bruker, Germany).Chemical compositions of the samples were analysed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Physical electronic PHI5000).The morphology and structure of the materials were studied by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S4800, Hitachi, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN, FEI, USA).UV-vis absorption spectra were collected using a UV/Vis/NIR spectrophotometer (Lambda 750, Perkin Elmer, USA). Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was acquired on an FTIR spectrophotometer (Spectrum One, Perkin Elmer, USA). The photoelectrochemical performance was tested in a three-electrode configuration with the as-prepared nanostructure as working electrode, Pt as counter electrode and SCE as reference electrode.All electrochemical measurements were carried out in CO 2 saturated 0.1 molL -1 KHCO 3 (pH was performed on the electrochemical workstation (CHI 660D, Chenhua, China) under the irradiation of Xe lamp (120 mWcm -2 ).The incident photon-to-current efficiency (IPCE) was obtained on the electrochemical workstation (IM6, Zahner, Germany) with a tunable light source (TLS 03, Zahner, Germany).The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and controlled intensity-modulated photocurrent spectroscopy (IMPS) were implemented using an electrochemical workstation (IM6, Zahner, Germany) under UV-visible light (100 mWcm -2 , WLC02, Zahner, Germany).The EIS measurements were carried out from 4 MHz to 1 mHz with an AC amplitude of of 0.20.9V (vs.RHE) on the electrochemical workstation (IM6, Zahner, Germany). The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was performed under both visible and UV-visible light irradiation in a gas-closed circulation system at 15 oC and a pressure of 2830 kPa.The 0.25 molL -1 Na 2 SO 3 and 1 molL -1 NaOH aqueous solution were used for the CO 2 photoreduction reaction.The electrodes of ZnO or ZnO/Cu 2 O heterostructures were placed in the solution and kept in upward direction.The system was purged with CO 2 for 90 min in dark to obtain maximum adsorption of CO 2 molecules on the active sites of the samples.Then a 300-W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300) was used to illuminate on the electrodes surface.A 420-nm cut-off filter was used to achieve the visible-light illumination.The identification of the products was valued by a gas chromatography system (GC, 7890A, Agilent, USA) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD), which was directly connected with the photochemical reaction system.The product yield was evaluated every one hour for totally 8 h in series.In-depth analysis on the structure of ZnO and ZnO/Cu 2 O-60s was further carried out by TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM).The length of the ZnO nanorods is 800 nm (Figure 3a).ZnO (0002) fringe is perpendicular to the rod axis with a lattice spacing of 0.26 nm on average (Figure 3b), indicating that ZnO nanorods grow along the 0001 direction as also confirmed by the XRD analysis.The selected area electron diffraction (SEAD) result further proves that the as-prepared ZnO nanorod is single crystalline (Figure 3c).3e).The SEAD of the heterostructure indicates that the Cu 2 O is polycrystalline (Figure 3f), indicating that the photodeposited Cu 2 O has high crystallinity and constructed by small particles, as also observed in the zoom-in SEM image (inset of Figure 2b).To further investigate the growth sites of the Cu 2 O particles, STEM imaging was carried out (Figure 3g).The Cu element mapping reveals that Cu only distributes on the tip of the ZnO nanorod, confirming the tip-selective deposition of the Cu 2 O particles.

light source.source: Significantly enhanced photoelectrochemical performance for the ZnO/Cu 2 O heterostructures under both UV-vis and visible illumination indicates that the p-n junction and spatially separated ZnO and Cu 2 O are in favour of generation, separation and transport of photogenerated charge carriers.
light source.context: ZnO/Cu photoconversion ability for the ZnO/Cu 2 O system in photcatalytic CO 2 Figure1ashows the XRD patterns of the ZnO nanorods and Figure 3e displays the interfacial region of the ZnO/Cu 2 O heterostructure photogenerated electrons can transfer much faster longitudinally than Figures 5a and 5b display the transient photocurrent response under Accordingly, the schematic band alignment of the ZnO/Cu 2 O junction in the electrolyte is drawn as shown in Scheme 2, which represents the equilibrium band model of the n-type ZnO and p-type Cu 2 O.According to the band alignment at the interface, a built-in electric field is established with the direction from n-type ZnO to p-type Cu 2 O.The electrons will be involved in the reduction reaction at n-type ZnO upon illumination and the holes will be located at p-type Cu 2 O to take part in the oxidation reaction.Due to the small size of Cu 2 O particles compared to the depletion layer width, transfer of the photoinduced electrons from the Cu 2 O to electrolyte will be blocked.Moreover, a thicker Cu 2 O layer means a larger depletion layer, which is more effective in enhancing the charge separation and collection.Therefore, the modulation of the band model at the electrode/electrolyte interface by introducing small Cu 2 O particles can reduce the electron-hole recombination, 2 O-30s exhibits almost the same photocatalytic activity as the pristine ZnO nanorods, due to the negligible influence on the heterostructure by the little amount of Cu 2 O. Compared to the ZnO nanorods, the photocatalytic activity is enhanced when the Cu 2 O content is increased, such as over the ZnO/Cu 2 O-45s catalyst.The CO amount further increases over the ZnO/Cu 2 O-60s sample, in that more Cu 2 O means higher efficiency for the generation, separation and transport of charge carriers, as confirmed by the above photoelectrochemical analysis.Moreover, the Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO nanorods can provide a large contact area between the ZnO and carbon source in the electrolyte, promoting the unidirectional transfer of holes to the Cu 2 O tip and electrons confined within the ZnO nanorods. Figure captions Figure 2. Top-view SEM images of the (a) ZnO nanorods and (b) ZnO /Cu 2 O-60s. Figure 3. TEM, HRTEM images and corresponding SEAD of (a, b, c) pristine ZnO Figure 4. UV-vis absorption spectra of the pristine ZnO nanorods and ZnO/Cu 2 O Figure 6.Photocatalytic evolution of CO over the ZnO nanorods and ZnO/Cu 2 O Figure 2. Figure 3. Figure 4. Photocurrent density /mAcm-2 2 O p-n heterostructure has been constructed by selectively photodepositing Cu 2 O on the tips of the ZnO nanorods.Structure analysis confirms the Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO nanorods mophorlogy and further proves the successful formation of ZnO/Cu 2 O p-n junction.Significantly enhanced photoelectrochemical performance for the ZnO/Cu 2 O heterostructures under both UV-vis and visible illumination indicates that the p-n junction and spatially separated ZnO and Cu 2 O are in favour of generation, separation and transport of photogenerated charge carriers.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction results also indicate that the Cu 2 O-tipped ZnO heterostructures are much more efficient than the pristine ZnO nanorods, demonstrating the potential application in photocatalysis.However, it is noted that the stability of Cu 2 O is the major concern of the obtained systems, which is a common weakness of the narrow bandgap semiconductor used in the fabrication of heterostructured photocatalysts.So further study is needed to mitigate this. Parameters determined from the Mott-Schottky measurements as well as the depletion layer width for different samples. Parameters determined from the Mott-Schottky measurements as well as the depletion layer width for different samples. This work was supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology of China (2015DFG62610).

nanorod, confirming the tip-selective deposition of the Cu 2 O particles.

reaction medium.source: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in aqueous solution under UV-visible light illumination shows that CO is the main product, and with the increase of the Cu 2 O content in the heterostructure, the CO yield increases.
